llm.feedback: Your draft captures the key drivers but needs tighter causal links, sharper numbers, and stricter citation discipline. 1) For each “Up/Down” line, replace the vague “Fed cuts + higher CPI” with the explicit chain: *US CPI > 2.5 % → Fed signals 3 cuts → 10‑yr yield falls 10–15 bp → term premium shrinks → DXY rises 50–100 bp* and cite (XTQIQRP5K)(Z7O1DCHS7). 2) The “Persistent tariff hikes” line must state the exact mechanism: *Tariff hikes (100 % semis, 50 % India) → Eurozone growth dampened → 10‑yr yields fall relative to UST → DXY gains 50–100 bp* and watch tariff announcements Aug 15‑Sep 30; cite (XTQIQRP5K). 3) The “CPI < 2.0 %” line should read: *CPI < 2.0 % → Fed pauses cuts → 10‑yr yields rise 5–10 bp → term premium steepens → DXY falls 50–100 bp* and cite (XTQIQRP5K). 4) The “2‑yr/10‑yr steepening” line must specify: *2‑yr/10‑yr spread rises to 57 bp → steepening compresses term premium → DXY drops ~200 bp* and watch the spread; cite (7XH2DKEKV). 5) Quantify probabilities from the source: use 70 % for the CPI‑cut scenario, 60 % for tariff‑driven rise, 55 % for CPI‑pause pullback, 45 % for steepening. 6) In the swing‑trade line, format exactly: *Up | 3‑6 mo | 99.0 | 97.5 | 100.5 | 1.5:1 | CPI < 2.0 % | CPI > 2.5 % | 70% | 80* and add inline citations for entry/stop/target logic (XTQIQRP5K)(Z7O1DCHS7)(7XH2DKEKV). 7) Remove any sentence that does not tie directly to DXY or its transmission path; every claim must have an inline ID. 8) Ensure no trailing citation list—only inline IDs. 9) Finally, double‑check that all numbers (e.g., 50–100 bp, 200 bp, 1.0–1.5 %) are sourced; if a range is not directly supported, narrow it to a single value with a citation. This will give the analysis the precision, causal clarity, and evidence‑based confidence required for a top‑macro PM.
